statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: UCLA 75, Long Beach State 62
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- UCLA was up, then down, then up at the end -- a young team unable to hold its big lead but good enough to recover. Dijon Thompson scored 25 points, helping the Bruins rally after blowing a 14-point lead in the second half of a 75-62 victory over Long Beach State on Tuesday night. "I'm glad we won the game because it got too tight," UCLA coach Ben Howland said. The Bruins are 4-0 for the first time since 1994-95, when they finished 32-1 and won their record 11th national championship. "We know we're 4-0, but that's not something we want to be cocky or confident about," freshman Arron Afflalo said. "We have a lot of things we need to work on." Afflalo added 21 points and six assists. He made all seven of his field-goal attempts and was 4-of-5 from the free-throw line. "I was so into the game, I didn't know I didn't miss a shot until just now," he said. Shawn Hawkins led Long Beach State (1-3) with a career-high-tying 15 points. He is the grandson of NBA Hall of Famer Connie Hawkins. The 49ers outscored UCLA 28-10 to start the second half and erase a 14-point deficit. A free throw by Tony Bryant ended the spurt and gave Long Beach State a 51-48 lead. "It hit me, we need to do something now," Afflalo said. "We need to make an effort." So they did. Thompson put the Bruins ahead for good on a pair of free throws after the game was tied at 55-all with 8½ minutes left. His total was one point off his career high of 26. In all, Thompson scored six straight points, hitting a hook shot and two more free throws for a 61-56 lead. "He really wanted to score," freshman Jordan Farmar said. "We have to give him the ball more. He's the senior, he knows what to do." Thompson surpassed the 1,000-point mark in his career, with 1,009. He declined to talk to reporters after the game. Afflalo hit a wide-open 3-pointer off a pass from Farmar, who scored on a fastbreak layin for a 66-56 lead. "That was really a turning point shot of the game," Howland said. Farmar finished with six points, six assists, three steals and four turnovers on his 18th birthday. "For about 33 minutes, we played a pretty good ballgame," Long Beach State coach Larry Reynolds said. "Our execution down the stretch was not what we wanted. UCLA did a good job the last seven minutes getting the ball inside and attacking us." The Bruins were outrebounded for the first time this season, 32-26, but held their fourth straight opponent to 40 percent or less field-goal shooting. The 49ers shot 40 percent and committed 19 turnovers to UCLA's 18. "A lot of the turnovers we had were forced," Howland said. "We're a very young team and we made some errors against pressure." UCLA is 10-0 against Long Beach State, which had a 17-6 edge on the offensive boards. The Bruins raced to a 10-point lead to start the game before the 49ers settled down and outscored them 17-4 to take a 19-16 lead. Farmar committed consecutive turnovers with the game tied at 16-all. Then it was UCLA's turn to dominate again. The Bruins outscored the 49ers 22-4, including seven points by Afflalo, who had a 3-pointer that ended the half with UCLA ahead 38-23. The Bruins were 12-of-14 from the line during the spurt, with Thompson making four in a row.
